item.title: As Trump lavishes money and praise on Argentina, more Americans ask: Why?
item.description: President Donald Trump has punished most U.S. trading partners with tariffs and threats, but he has lavished favours on Javier Milei's Argentina, including a $20 billion bailout of its currency. item.title: Inuit leader replaced amid allegations of abuse
item.description: The Manitoba Inuit Association has appointed an interim CEO, as a petition with more than 1,200 signatures circulates calling on the non-profit organization to look into allegations of sexual and physical abuse against its CEO, Nastania Mullin. It’s part of what some are calling an #InuitMeToo grassroots campaign.

The Manitoba Inuit Association has appointed an interim CEO, as a petition with more than 1,200 signatures circulates calling on the non-profit organization to look into allegations of sexual and physical abuse against its CEO, Nastania Mullin. It’s part of what some are calling an #InuitMeToo grassroots campaign.

item.title: Pope approves beatification for priests martyred under Nazism and Communism
item.description:
Pope Leo XIV approves the upcoming beatification of nine Polish priests martyred at Dachau and Auschwitz; and two diocesan priests killed out of “hatred of the faith” by the Communist regime that ruled Czechoslovakia in the 1950s. The Holy Father also promulgates decrees concerning four new Venerables: a Spanish Cistercian nun, a Spanish Dominican priest, an Italian diocesan priest, and an Italian Carmelite friar.

Read all
item.source:markdown:

The Holy Father also promulgates decrees concerning four new Venerables: a Spanish Cistercian nun, a Spanish Dominican priest, an Italian diocesan priest, and an Italian Carmelite friar.

item.description:
Pope Leo XIV reminds pilgrims from Estonia in Rome for the Jubilee that their ecumenical witness is the "very antithesis of the hatred that was so tragically visible during the Soviet regime’s persecution of the Church" and urges them "to pray fervently for peace" while "we still see the logic of war being perpetrated in Europe."

item.title: How 3 women beat Singapore’s strict protest laws | About That
item.description: In Singapore, protesting without permission from police is illegal, but that didn’t stop three women from organizing a watermelon umbrella march in solidarity with the Palestinian cause. Andrew Chang explains the charges against the organizers by breaking down Singapore’s strict rules on public assembly — and why these three women were ultimately acquitted. Images from Ng Yi-Sheng/Facebook, sgacadboycott/Instagram, MustShareNews, Getty Images, Reuters Thumbnail credit: sgacadboycott/Instagram
item.source:markdown:
![Photo of 3 women who beat Singapore’s strict protest laws.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/3cfe0263-4400-4c96-a2fc-23cca7688ab0,1761250813022/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C0%2C1920%2C1080%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
In Singapore, protesting without permission from police is illegal, but that didn’t stop three women from organizing a watermelon umbrella march in solidarity with the Palestinian cause. Andrew Chang explains the charges against the organizers by breaking down Singapore’s strict rules on public assembly — and why these three women were ultimately acquitted.
Images from Ng Yi-Sheng/Facebook, sgacadboycott/Instagram, MustShareNews, Getty Images, Reuters
Thumbnail credit: sgacadboycott/Instagram

item.title: King Charles receives Royal Confrater title as sign of 'hope' with Anglican Communion
item.description:
The British monarch is accorded the title "Royal Confrater" at the Basilica of Saint Paul Outside the Walls, taking a seat on a stall bearing the Gospel inscription, “That they may be one”. This wish is echoed by Cardinal Harvey, who, together with Abbot Ogliari, accompanies the Royals through the Holy Door before the ecumenical celebration.

Read all

item.title: Fraternity and hope strengthen relations between Catholics and Anglicans
item.description:
Perspectives on the visit of the British Royal Family to the Vatican by Archbishop Pace, secretary of the Pontifical Council for Christian Unity, and Bishop Ball, director of the Anglican Centre in Rome. The warmth and gestures that accompanied it “nurture our confidence in the path of dialogue and engagement with one another to which our churches remain wholeheartedly committed. We continue to hope, as Pope Leo has expressed it, for ‘the re-establishment of full and visible communion.’”

Read all
item.source:markdown:

We continue to hope, as Pope Leo has expressed it, for ‘the re-establishment of full and visible communion.’”

item.title: Fragile Gaza ceasefire marks ‘a momentous but precarious juncture,’ UN envoy tells Security Council
item.description: The Gaza ceasefire provides a rare opportunity to end one of the most destructive phases of the wider Israel-Palestine conflict, the UN’s deputy Middle East envoy told the Security Council on Thursday.
item.source:markdown: The Gaza ceasefire provides a rare opportunity to end one of the most destructive phases of the wider Israel-Palestine conflict, the UN’s deputy Middle East envoy told the Security Council on Thursday.

item.title: Security Council LIVE: Gaza ceasefire, aid crisis dominates agenda as ambassadors meet on the Middle East
item.description: The UN Security Council is meeting in New York to debate the Middle East. The session comes amid faltering progress on the fragile Gaza ceasefire and mounting humanitarian needs after two years of war, with famine still looming in parts of the territory. Ambassadors will likely discuss yesterday's ICJ advisory opinion affirming Israel’s obligation to allow agencies aid access under international law. Follow our in-depth live coverage from 10am; UN News app users can go here.
item.source:markdown: The UN Security Council is meeting in New York to debate the Middle East. The session comes amid faltering progress on the fragile Gaza ceasefire and mounting humanitarian needs after two years of war, with famine still looming in parts of the territory. Ambassadors will likely discuss yesterday's ICJ advisory opinion affirming Israel’s obligation to allow agencies aid access under international law. Follow our in-depth live coverage from 10am; UN News app users can go here.

item.title: Ceasefire offers ‘lifeline’ but Gaza hospitals remain in ruins
item.description: Gaza’s health system remains in ruins despite the fragile ceasefire holding, with hundreds of thousands still facing urgent medical and humanitarian needs, the head of the World Health Organization (WHO) warned on Thursday.

item.title: Millions pushed to ‘brink of survival’ in Sudan
item.description: Over 900 days of brutal conflict, widespread human rights violations, famine, and the collapse of essential services have driven millions of people in Sudan to the “brink of survival” – with women and children bearing the heaviest burden.

item.title: Forty migrants, including children, perish in Tunisia shipwreck

item.title: Trump's pressure on Venezuela raises spectre of coup or invasion. Either scenario faces major hurdles
item.description: The buildup of U.S. military forces near Venezuela and a series of deadly attacks on alleged drug-trafficking boats in waters off its coast has raised the spectre of an invasion of the South American country. Yet that still appears unlikely, some experts say, as any military action launched by the Trump administration would face significant resistance.
item.source:markdown:
![Armed demonstrators march in support of President Nicolas Maduro in Caracas, Venezuela, Tuesday, Sept. 23, 2025.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/5ef1b237-a232-4e42-8f5d-ec06228bfdc7,1761169989719/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C450%2C8640%2C4860%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
The buildup of U.S. military forces near Venezuela and a series of deadly attacks on alleged drug-trafficking boats in waters off its coast has raised the spectre of an invasion of the South American country. Yet that still appears unlikely, some experts say, as any military action launched by the Trump administration would face significant resistance.

item.title: Why French ex-president Nicolas Sarkozy is now in jail | About That
item.description: How does a former French president end up behind bars in the isolation wing of a Paris prison? item.title: Security Council LIVE: UN discusses next phase to curb Haiti gang violence, step up aid
item.description: Following renewal of the Security Council’s sanctions regime in Haiti and a resolution to create a new Gang Suppression Force to combat the scourge of gang violence, ambassadors heard this afternoon from the top UN official in the country. In his first briefing as head of the UN office in Haiti (BINUH), Carlos Ruiz Massieu reported on latest developments, as brutal violence and insecurity continues to rage, increasing pressure on diplomats to act fast and decisively to protect millions of Haitians facing impunity and chaos. UN News app users can follow live coverage here.
item.source:markdown: Following renewal of the Security Council’s sanctions regime in Haiti and a resolution to create a new Gang Suppression Force to combat the scourge of gang violence, ambassadors heard this afternoon from the top UN official in the country. item.title: Russia holds nuclear drills, Ukraine seeks fighter jets

item.title: Economy to grow faster than expected this year - Goodbody
item.description: The Irish economy will grow faster than anticipated this year as impact of US tariffs will not be as damaging as feared and the country "dodged a bullet" on US corporation tax changes, according to a new report by Goodbody Stockbrokers.
item.source:markdown: The Irish economy will grow faster than anticipated this year as impact of US tariffs will not be as damaging as feared and the country "dodged a bullet" on US corporation tax changes, according to a new report by Goodbody Stockbrokers.

item.title: Woman whose partner died after Winnipeg police encounter files lawsuit against officers, city

item.title: Child fell off Disney cruise ship after mom told her to pose for photo on railing, police say
item.description: A five-year-old girl who fell overboard from a Disney Dream cruise ship in June had been posing for a photo at the request of her mother, according to Florida authorities in reports obtained by CBC News. The girl and her father, who jumped in after her, were both rescued.
item.source:markdown:
![A cruise ship](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/7d05b7ca-50a0-44a5-b28a-f79593922435,1761073463059/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C193%2C4944%2C2781%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)

item.title: How wacky inflatable costumes are changing the narrative around U.S. protests
item.description: Whether it’s the ongoing anti-ICE protests in Portland and Los Angeles, or the massive No Kings rallies that swept across the U.S. this weekend, the crowds are full of cutesy, cartoonish and colourful frogs, chickens, lobsters, dinosaurs, axolotls, unicorns and more.
item.source:markdown:
![Aperson in a giant inflatable frog costume, with a crown on its head, a protest flag in one hand and and a Quiznos sub in the other. On its stomach are stickers that read: "No Kings in America" and "Don't Obey."](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/b80abcb9-2577-444e-83ca-cc087f151c06,1761064978819/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C312%2C6000%2C3375%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
Whether it’s the ongoing anti-ICE protests in Portland and Los Angeles, or the massive No Kings rallies that swept across the U.S. this weekend, the crowds are full of cutesy, cartoonish and colourful frogs, chickens, lobsters, dinosaurs, axolotls, unicorns and more.

item.title: Cupich on 'Dilexi te': the Liturgy as a place of solidarity with the poor
item.description:
Cardinal Cupich, Archbishop of Chicago, reflects for Vatican News on Pope Leo XIV's first Apostolic Exhortation. In his meditation he recalls the words of Saint John XXIII before opening the Second Vatican Council: the Church must be the Church of all and “particularly the Church of the poor.”

Read all
item.source:markdown:
Cardinal Cupich, Archbishop of Chicago, reflects for Vatican News on Pope Leo XIV's first Apostolic Exhortation. In his meditation he recalls the words of Saint John XXIII before opening the Second Vatican Council: the Church must be the Church of all and “particularly the Church of the poor.”

item.title: France's Sarkozy: from palace to prison

item.title: An advocate in a veil: Catholic sister defending justice in Kenyan courtrooms
item.description:
When people picture a Catholic religious sister, they image a woman in a habit, perhaps teaching, praying quietly in a chapel, or caring for the sick. Few imagine a religious sister in a courtroom, dressed in professional attire, standing before a judge, and introducing herself not just as “Advocate Immaculate Muthoni,” but as “Sister Immaculate.”

Read all
item.source:markdown:
When people picture a Catholic religious sister, they image a woman in a habit, perhaps teaching, praying quietly in a chapel, or caring for the sick. Few imagine a religious sister in a courtroom, dressed in professional attire, standing before a judge, and introducing herself not just as “Advocate Immaculate Muthoni,” but as “Sister Immaculate.”
[Read all](https://www.vaticannews.va/en/church/news/2025-10/sisters-project-150-kenya-lawyer-nun-defending-justice.html)

item.title: Sri Lankan Church renews call for Special Prosecutor for Easter Sunday attacks

More than six years after the 2019 Easter Sunday bombings, the Sri Lankan Church is urging the government to appoint a special prosecutor to ensure justice for the victims. Fr Rohan Silva, OMI, says the Church will “keep up the pressure” until truth and accountability are achieved.

item.title: Trump ending aid to Colombia after U.S. accused of murder for boat strike
item.description: U.S. President Donald Trump says he is ending aid to Colombia after the country’s president, Gustavo Petro, accused the U.S. of ‘murder’ when it struck a small boat within Colombian territorial waters in September. The U.S. alleges the boat was a drug vessel, but Petro said the fisherman killed onboard had no ties to the drug trade.
item.source:markdown:
![U.S. President Donald Trump on the left and Columbia's president Gustavo Petro on the right](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/6c02cfdf-e2af-46b3-8366-712596d98f7e,1760903880044/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C0%2C1280%2C720%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
U.S. President Donald Trump says he is ending aid to Colombia after the country’s president, Gustavo Petro, accused the U.S. of ‘murder’ when it struck a small boat within Colombian territorial waters in September. The U.S. alleges the boat was a drug vessel, but Petro said the fisherman killed onboard had no ties to the drug trade.

item.title: Comments by Humphreys a 'new low', says Connolly

item.title: Giant Russian gas plant suspends intake from Kazakhstan after Ukrainian drone strike

The Orenburg gas processing plant, the largest facility of its kind in the world, has been forced to suspend its intake of gas from Kazakhstan after a Ukrainian drone attack, Kazakhstan's Ministry of Energy said on Sunday.

item.title: Ceasefire strained as Israel hits Gaza with deadly strikes over IDF deaths
item.description: The Israeli military said on Sunday that a ceasefire in Gaza had resumed after an attack that killed two of its soldiers and prompted a wave of airstrikes that killed 26 people, in the most serious test yet of this month's U.S.-brokered truce.

![People run for cover in a war-torn street.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/108e9317-c036-4e13-b5be-89e036f64b18,1760902741496/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C285%2C5472%2C3078%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)

item.title: Thieves in balaclavas, on motorbikes steal crown jewels in Louvre heist
item.description: Thieves in balaclavas broke into Paris's Louvre museum on Sunday, using a crane to smash an upstairs window, then stealing priceless objects from an area that houses the French crown jewels before escaping on motorbikes, officials said.

Thieves in balaclavas broke into Paris's Louvre museum on Sunday, using a crane to smash an upstairs window, then stealing priceless objects from an area that houses the French crown jewels before escaping on motorbikes, officials said.

item.description: A wave of Gen Z protests have spread across the world from South East Asia to Sub Saharan Africa, with a range of grievances from govenment corruption to poor public services to internet censorship. item.title: These wool producers are aiming to revitalize the natural fibre’s value in Europe
item.description: Across Europe and North America, the picture is bleak: wool is often burned or discarded because processing costs outweigh returns. ![A flock of sheep with pink dots painted on their backs are seen packed close together. ](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/7aa51428-63de-42af-be88-6f4dd3f78a4d,1760636370153/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C378%2C4032%2C2268%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)

item.title: Trump, Putin to meet after progress in Ukraine talks

item.title: Trump says he'll meet with Putin again after 'great progress' in Thursday phone call
item.description: U.S. President Donald Trump said Thursday he will meet again with Russian President Vladimir Putin in person, in an effort to end the war in Ukraine. A date has not been set, but Trump wrote on social media that the meeting would take place in Budapest, Hungary. The call came ahead of Trump's meeting on Friday at the White House with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy.

item.title: World Food Day LIVE: The task of feeding the world
item.description: Amid the destruction of the Second World War, nations responded to the danger of hunger and malnutrition by creating the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) on 16 October 1945. The UN agency celebrates this achievement as World Food Day every year on its birthday, recognizing the work of all those who are committed to ensuring food for everyone. We’ll be bringing you the highlights live from FAO throughout the day. UN News app users can follow coverage here.
item.source:markdown: Amid the destruction of the Second World War, nations responded to the danger of hunger and malnutrition by creating the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) on 16 October 1945. The UN agency celebrates this achievement as World Food Day every year on its birthday, recognizing the work of all those who are committed to ensuring food for everyone. We’ll be bringing you the highlights live from FAO throughout the day. UN News app users can follow coverage here.

item.title: Trump's Gaza deal may be 'historic,' but falls short of delivering 'dawn of a new Middle East'
item.description: The killing has stopped. Surviving Israeli hostages have been released to their families, while hundreds of Palestinians held by Israel have been returned to theirs. But to call an end to the Gaza war, as Trump did, the “historic dawn of a new Middle East” wildly overstates what the deal delivers.
item.source:markdown:
![A swath of road is filled with people walking north, with dusty land on either side and buildings along the horizon.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/33a06d0a-b9ec-4d21-8ce4-403e4d8e8cc6,1760624324928/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C138%2C2645%2C1487%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
The killing has stopped. Surviving Israeli hostages have been released to their families, while hundreds of Palestinians held by Israel have been returned to theirs. But to call an end to the Gaza war, as Trump did, the “historic dawn of a new Middle East” wildly overstates what the deal delivers.

item.title: A saint to be for a nation: Peter To Rot’s witness shapes Papua New Guinea
item.description:
Pope St. John Paul II declared Peter To Rot Blessed, in 1995, as the first Martyr of Papua New Guinea, as a new figure of holiness is a layman a husband, father, teacher, and catechist. Pope Francis approved his canonization on March 31, 2025, and he will be canonized on 19 October 2025 by Pope Leo XIV and be formally recognized as the first saint from Papua New Guinea, and six other Blesseds from other countries.

Read all
item.source:markdown:
Pope St. John Paul II declared Peter To Rot Blessed, in 1995, as the first Martyr of Papua New Guinea, as a new figure of holiness is a layman a husband, father, teacher, and catechist. Pope Francis approved his canonization on March 31, 2025, and he will be canonized on 19 October 2025 by Pope Leo XIV and be formally recognized as the first saint from Papua New Guinea, and six other Blesseds from other countries.

item.title: Indigenous-led film finds perfect home on First Nation in Sask.
item.description: When Rueben Martell was looking for locations to shoot his Indigenous love story A Life Less Empty, he knew he wanted it to be on a reserve in his home province of Saskatchewan. After months of searching, he and his film crew finally found the ideal location — an abandoned house on Pheasant Rump Nakota Nation, about 150 kilometres southeast of Regina.
item.source:markdown:
![An Indigenous man standing in front of an old house on a movie set](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/97c0c19c-a8b8-4835-92f7-99b3686a8f36,1760574486850/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C561%2C5712%2C3213%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
When Rueben Martell was looking for locations to shoot his Indigenous love story A Life Less Empty, he knew he wanted it to be on a reserve in his home province of Saskatchewan. item.description: Alberta beef is now stocked in the meat section of Costco Mexico's 41 locations, joining a host of other Canadian products on the shelves of the retail giant in the country. Agriculture Minister Heath MacDonald was on hand for a ribbon cutting in front of a Costco cooler filled with prime Alberta cuts during a weeklong visit to the country.

![A man in a suit speaks with a shorter woman with a facemask on at a Costco.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/8dffce6e-4eba-4897-bab1-485b01a98095,1760556366580/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C154%2C4032%2C2268%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
Alberta beef is now stocked in the meat section of Costco Mexico's 41 locations, joining a host of other Canadian products on the shelves of the retail giant in the country. item.title: He's one of the most celebrated Indigenous artists — and one of the most forged
item.description: A new podcast, Forged, investigates the massive art forgery of Norval Morrisseau's paintings. Today on Commotion, Forged host and Indigenous artist Adrian Stimson sits down with host Elamin Abdelmahmoud to discuss what is possibly the largest art crime fraud ever.

item.title: Tanzania: On Nyerere Day, Archbishop Ruwa’ichi calls for an end to abductions
item.description:
In commemorating Nyerere Day—when Tanzanians honour the country’s Founding Father, Mwalimu Julius Kambarage Nyerere—on 14 October 2025, the Archbishop of the Archdiocese of Dar es Salaam and Chairperson of the Justice and Peace Commission for the Tanzania Episcopal Conference (TEC) issued a passionate appeal concerning a troubling rise in unexplained disappearances and kidnappings across the country. The abductions have persisted in Tanzania for the past two years.

Read all
item.source:markdown:
In commemorating Nyerere Day—when Tanzanians honour the country’s Founding Father, Mwalimu Julius Kambarage Nyerere—on 14 October 2025, the Archbishop of the Archdiocese of Dar es Salaam and Chairperson of the Justice and Peace Commission for the Tanzania Episcopal Conference (TEC) issued a passionate appeal concerning a troubling rise in unexplained disappearances and kidnappings across the country. The abductions have persisted in Tanzania for the past two years.
[Read all](https://www.vaticannews.va/en/africa/news/2025-10/tanzania-on-nyerere-day-archbishop-ruwa-ichi-calls-for-an-end.html)

item.title: Portugal superstar Ronaldo sets goalscoring record in World Cup qualifiers

item.title: Pragmatism and positivity: How Canada and India are framing a reset of strained ties
item.description: After two years of navigating a bitter diplomatic spat over the killing of a Sikh activist on Canadian soil, India and Canada have tentatively sketched out a road map to rebuild their strained relationship. That's the end result of a two-day visit to New Delhi and Mumbai — one which Canadian Foreign Minister Anita Anand has called a success.
item.source:markdown:
![A woman with dark hair, wearing a red jack and scarf, smiles as sit sits for a portrait.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/4f4200ce-5ebc-4ec6-a4f6-dfa4ff34287d,1760453807152/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%28258%2C83%2C3902%2C2194%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
After two years of navigating a bitter diplomatic spat over the killing of a Sikh activist on Canadian soil, India and Canada have tentatively sketched out a road map to rebuild their strained relationship. That's the end result of a two-day visit to New Delhi and Mumbai — one which Canadian Foreign Minister Anita Anand has called a success.

item.title: Indirect disaster effects cost the world nearly $2 trillion per year, Guterres says on International Day
item.description: From 1970 until 2000, the costs of disaster averaged $70-$80 billion. Those mainly preventable costs doubled this century to average $180-$200 billion annually, according to a recent report published by the UN Office for Disaster Risk Reduction (UNDRR).

item.title: ‘We resist by simply existing on the land’: Ramallah mayor on life under occupation
item.description: Ramallah, in the Occupied Palestinian Territory of the West Bank, is a bustling urban centre, but it is ringed by barriers and checkpoints which dominate every aspect of life. item.title: Holy See at UN: Build lasting peace through development, not military spending
item.description:
In 2024 global military spending reached $2.7 trillion, while the funding gap for the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) remains at $4 trillion per year. For every dollar invested in peace, two are spent on war. Archbishop Gabriele Caccia, Permanent Observer of the Holy See to the United Nations tells the UN that: “Every increase in military spending represents resources that could have been used to meet people’s basic needs and to establish a lasting peace.”

Read all
item.source:markdown:
In 2024 global military spending reached $2.7 trillion, while the funding gap for the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) remains at $4 trillion per year. For every dollar invested in peace, two are spent on war. Archbishop Gabriele Caccia, Permanent Observer of the Holy See to the United Nations tells the UN that: “Every increase in military spending represents resources that could have been used to meet people’s basic needs and to establish a lasting peace.”
[Read all](https://www.vaticannews.va/en/vatican-city/news/2025-10/holy-see-at-un-build-peace-with-development-not-arms-spending.html)

item.title: Naskapi teen attends international science fair
item.description: Aiden-James Einish from the Naskapi Nation of Kawawachikamach in northern Quebec was one of 36 students in Canada selected to attend the Expo-Sciences International science fair in Abu Dhabi, U.A.E., Sept. 29 to Oct. 1. Einish, 16, won the opportunity after receiving a bronze medal at the Canada Wide Science Fair in June. His project looked at how the traditional use of the Labrador Tea plant can reduce inflammation from arthritis. Einish talked to CBC Indigenous about his experiences in the Middle East and what’s next.
item.source:markdown:
![First Nations teenager in red jacket stands next to teacher in front of a science fair both. Text reads "CBC Trip to Abu Dhabi."](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/96eb249e-cf1a-4c39-9359-f28ed780917b,1760115160002/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C0%2C512%2C288%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
Aiden-James Einish from the Naskapi Nation of Kawawachikamach in northern Quebec was one of 36 students in Canada selected to attend the Expo-Sciences International science fair in Abu Dhabi, U.A.E., Sept. 29 to Oct. 1.
Einish, 16, won the opportunity after receiving a bronze medal at the Canada Wide Science Fair in June. His project looked at how the traditional use of the Labrador Tea plant can reduce inflammation from arthritis.
Einish talked to CBC Indigenous about his experiences in the Middle East and what’s next.

item.description: Nearly four million people across Africa’s vast semi-arid Sahel region have been uprooted by a volatile mix of conflict, hunger and climate change, the UN warned on Friday, describing an unfolding protection and survival crisis that is pushing families to flee repeatedly.

item.title: Security Council LIVE: Ambassadors meet over US strikes against alleged drug traffickers off Venezuela
item.description: The UN Security Council went into emergency session on Friday, following a request from Venezuela. The United States military has carried out four deadly air strikes in Caribbean waters over the past few weeks against what Washington alleges are Caracas-backed drug traffickers. The Venezuelan Government denies the charge, accusing the administration of being a threat to the peace and security of the whole region. Follow live coverage below and UN News app users can go here.

item.title: Pope Leo in 'Dilexi te': Faith cannot be separated from love for the poor
item.description:
Taking up Pope Francis’ desire “that all Christians come to appreciate the close connection between Christ’s love and His summons to care for the poor,” Pope Leo XIV issues his first Apostolic Exhortation, “Dilexi te,” as a call to Christ’s disciples “to recognize him in the poor and the suffering.”

Read all
item.source:markdown:
Taking up Pope Francis’ desire “that all Christians come to appreciate the close connection between Christ’s love and His summons to care for the poor,” Pope Leo XIV issues his first Apostolic Exhortation, “Dilexi te,” as a call to Christ’s disciples “to recognize him in the poor and the suffering.”
[Read all](https://www.vaticannews.va/en/pope/news/2025-10/pope-leo-faith-cannot-be-separated-from-love-for-the-poor.html)

item.title: Peter reminds us that the poor are the heart of the Gospel
item.description:
In his first Apostolic Exhortation, “Dilexi te” Pope Leo XIV sets out the foundations of Christian Revelation and of the tradition of the Church.

item.title: Pope: In this age of communication, nobody can say 'I did not know'
item.description:
Addressing a global network of leading news agencies, Pope Leo thanks reporters who every day work to share the truth, often risking their lives. It is thanks to them, he says, that we have knowledge of the world.

Read all

item.title: Peace deal shows rare hope after brutal two years of war
item.description: After two years of war and numerous false dawns on the prospect of a ceasefire, last night marked a major breakthrough as Israel and Hamas finally signed off on the first phase of a Gaza peace plan.

item.title: Shelter-in-place advisory in Ginoogaming First Nation lifted after 2 suspects located
item.description: A shelter-in-place advisory for Ginoogaming First Nation has been lifted. Police issued the advisory on Wednesday as they searched for two individuals said to be armed and dangerous. One person has been found deceased and another injured, but police have not yet provided further details. Thursday evening, the OPP said the two suspects had been found.
item.source:markdown:
![A sign next to a road welcomes people to Ginoogaming First Nation](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/1e18382d-cfa2-4d4e-93c1-fc788e291820,1760010749861/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C0%2C842%2C473%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
A shelter-in-place advisory for Ginoogaming First Nation has been lifted. Police issued the advisory on Wednesday as they searched for two individuals said to be armed and dangerous. One person has been found deceased and another injured, but police have not yet provided further details. Thursday evening, the OPP said the two suspects had been found.

item.title: European Court of Auditors warns on EU debt levels

item.title: Why Trump's team is portraying Antifa as a terrorist threat

item.title: ‘A historic moment’: Mikisew Cree First Nation opens new child and family services agency in Fort McMurray
item.description: Fort McMurray is now home to a new Delegated First Nations child and family services agency — the Mikisew Awasis Kisiwatsowin Society — which will deliver child protection services and prevention support to families living on reserve in the Mikisew Cree First Nation.

item.title: Pope Leo greets Hispanic ministry leaders from the USA
item.description:
Pope Leo XIV met on Tuesday evening in the Vatican with more than a hundred leaders of Hispanic ministry from the United States. He encouraged them to be witnesses of God's love and to accompany especially the poor and migrants. He reminded them that "God never abandons anyone" and thanked them for their pastoral service, calling it a sign of hope and faith in a world wounded by violence and hatred.

Read all
item.source:markdown:
Pope Leo XIV met on Tuesday evening in the Vatican with more than a hundred leaders of Hispanic ministry from the United States. He encouraged them to be witnesses of God's love and to accompany especially the poor and migrants. He reminded them that "God never abandons anyone" and thanked them for their pastoral service, calling it a sign of hope and faith in a world wounded by violence and hatred.
[Read all](https://www.vaticannews.va/en/pope/news/2025-10/pope-leo-greets-hispanic-ministry-leaders-from-the-usa.html)

item.title: Kate McCann tells court of distress over alleged stalkers
item.description: The mother of missing toddler Madeleine McCann was left distressed after being confronted on her driveway by two women accused of stalking her, including a Polish national who has falsely claimed to be Madeleine, a court heard.
item.source:markdown: The mother of missing toddler Madeleine McCann was left distressed after being confronted on her driveway by two women accused of stalking her, including a Polish national who has falsely claimed to be Madeleine, a court heard.

item.title: Man rescued from tree as north Vietnam sees powerful floods
item.description: Footage released by Cao Bang Public Security in Vietnam shows rescue crews ferrying a man to safety after strong storms triggered by a typhoon led to swollen rivers and flooded streets.

item.title: South African president welcomed to Áras an Uachtaráin
item.description: President Michael D Higgins has welcomed South African President Cyril Ramaphosa to Áras an Uachtaráin for what is understood to be the last State visit during his term.
item.source:markdown: President Michael D Higgins has welcomed South African President Cyril Ramaphosa to Áras an Uachtaráin for what is understood to be the last State visit during his term.

item.title: Syria’s search for truth is a ‘collective effort’, top UN investigator says
item.description: Tens of thousands of people went missing in Syria over the past 50 years under the Assad dictatorship, including during 14 years of civil war which began in 2011.
item.source:markdown: Tens of thousands of people went missing in Syria over the past 50 years under the Assad dictatorship, including during 14 years of civil war which began in 2011.

item.title: Peace begins behind bars: A corrections officer’s fight for dignity inside Congo’s prisons
item.description: The offer sounded almost unreal. The UN was fishing around for someone with a knack for building prisons – preferably a woman – to join its mission in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC). Would she go?
item.source:markdown: The offer sounded almost unreal. The UN was fishing around for someone with a knack for building prisons – preferably a woman – to join its mission in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC). Would she go?

item.title: Haiti: ‘Unprecedented’ number of children on the run
item.description: The number of children displaced by violence in Haiti has almost doubled in the past year, with 680,000 now uprooted from their homes, a new UN Children’s Fund (UNICEF) Child Alert report found.
item.source:markdown: The number of children displaced by violence in Haiti has almost doubled in the past year, with 680,000 now uprooted from their homes, a new UN Children’s Fund (UNICEF) Child Alert report found.

item.title: Ministers from Europe and beyond commit to address housing emergency
item.description: Across Europe and beyond, housing costs are rising faster than incomes and many families are spending up to half their salary just to have a place to call home.
item.source:markdown: Across Europe and beyond, housing costs are rising faster than incomes and many families are spending up to half their salary just to have a place to call home.

item.title: WHO says rebuilding Gaza’s shattered health system critical to a lasting peace
item.description: As indirect talks in Egypt seeking to end Gaza’s two-year war continue, the UN World Health Organization (WHO) says rebuilding the devastated health system is critical to securing lasting peace and stability.
item.source:markdown: As indirect talks in Egypt seeking to end Gaza’s two-year war continue, the UN World Health Organization (WHO) says rebuilding the devastated health system is critical to securing lasting peace and stability.

item.title: UN chief ‘deeply saddened’ by deadly protests in Madagascar
item.description: UN Secretary-General António Guterres has stressed the need for dialogue in Madagascar as anti-government demonstrations enter a third week.
item.source:markdown: UN Secretary-General António Guterres has stressed the need for dialogue in Madagascar as anti-government demonstrations enter a third week.

item.title: UN chief calls for Israel and Hamas to ‘abide fully’ by terms of US peace plan
item.description: The UN Secretary-General has welcomed the announcement from US President Donald Trump that Israel and Hamas have “signed off” on the first phase of his 20-point peace plan, following days of intensive indirect negotiations in Egypt.
item.source:markdown: The UN Secretary-General has welcomed the announcement from US President Donald Trump that Israel and Hamas have “signed off” on the first phase of his 20-point peace plan, following days of intensive indirect negotiations in Egypt.

item.title: UN decries deadly Myanmar airstrike, amid mounting military attacks on civilians
item.description: The United Nations has condemned a Myanmar airstrike that killed dozens of civilians, including children, calling it part of a “disturbing pattern” of indiscriminate attacks by the country’s military.
item.source:markdown: The United Nations has condemned a Myanmar airstrike that killed dozens of civilians, including children, calling it part of a “disturbing pattern” of indiscriminate attacks by the country’s military.

item.title: DRC Bishops dismayed by death sentence against former President Kabila
item.description:
In the aftermath of the death sentence pronounced by the High Military Court against former Congolese President Joseph Kabila, Bishops in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) under the auspices of the Conférence épiscopale nationale du Congo (CENCO) have said that they are dismayed and shocked by the verdict.

Read all
item.source:markdown:
In the aftermath of the death sentence pronounced by the High Military Court against former Congolese President Joseph Kabila, Bishops in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) under the auspices of the Conférence épiscopale nationale du Congo (CENCO) have said that they are dismayed and shocked by the verdict.

item.description: Zelda Williams — actress, director and daughter to the late actor Robin Williams — has spoken out on Instagram about what she calls "disgusting" AI recreations of her father.

item.description: Opposition parties have heavily criticised the Government's budget plans, saying they are designed to help developers instead of ordinary people, have done "nothing" for workers and ignore the biggest crises facing Irish society.

item.title: Gold prices hit record high as anxious investors seek safe haven for money
item.description: Gold futures have soared above $4,000 US per troy ounce for the first time, as many investors seek a safe place to park their money as the U.S. government shutdown continues.
item.source:markdown:
![FILE - In this Tuesday, July 22, 2014, file photo, gold bars are stacked in a vault at the United States Mint, in West Point, N.Y. The price of gold has climbed recently as investors scramble for safety amid the widening global trade war. It’s up nearly 5% since May 21, 2019, as stock markets around the world fell, and last week was the best of the year for gold after President Donald Trump surprised markets by threatening to raise tariffs on Mexico. (AP Photo/Mike Groll, File)](https://i.cbc.ca/1.5190145.1742497088!/fileImage/httpImage/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/16x9_620/off-the-charts-gold.jpg)
Gold futures have soared above $4,000 US per troy ounce for the first time, as many investors seek a safe place to park their money as the U.S. government shutdown continues.

item.title: Pensions, social welfare payments to rise by €10 weekly
item.description: The Government has announced a weekly increase of €10 per person in a range of social protection payments from 2026, including: the State pension, disability allowance, carer's allowance, jobseeker's allowance and one-parent family payment.
item.source:markdown: The Government has announced a weekly increase of €10 per person in a range of social protection payments from 2026, including: the State pension, disability allowance, carer's allowance, jobseeker's allowance and one-parent family payment.

item.title: 50c on pack of cigarettes, alcohol duty unchanged
item.description: The duty on a pack of 20 cigarettes will be increased by 50c as part of Budget 2026, however excise duty on alcohol is unchanged.
item.source:markdown: The duty on a pack of 20 cigarettes will be increased by 50c as part of Budget 2026, however excise duty on alcohol is unchanged.

item.title: Bob Ross paintings will be auctioned in support of U.S. public TV stations
item.description: Thirty paintings by Ross, whose TV show The Joy of Painting aired on public TV stations in the 1980s and 90s, will be auctioned off with proceeds going to stations that use content from distributor American Public Television. The idea is to help stations in need with licensing fees.

Thirty paintings by Ross, whose TV show The Joy of Painting aired on public TV stations in the 1980s and 90s, will be auctioned off with proceeds going to stations that use content from distributor American Public Television. The idea is to help stations in need with licensing fees.

item.title: Carbon tax to be increased to €71 per tonne of CO2
item.description: Carbon tax is to increase by €7.50 to €71 per tonne of CO2 emitted, which will be applied to auto fuels with effect from tomorrow, and to all other fuels from 1 May 2026.
item.source:markdown: Carbon tax is to increase by €7.50 to €71 per tonne of CO2 emitted, which will be applied to auto fuels with effect from tomorrow, and to all other fuels from 1 May 2026.

item.title: Renewables become biggest source of electricity globally for 1st time, beating coal
item.description: Worldwide solar and wind power generation has outpaced electricity demand this year, and for the first time on record, renewable energies combined generated more power than coal, according to a new analysis.
item.source:markdown:
![Workers install solar panels at the under-construction Adani Green Energy Limited's Renewable Energy Park in the salt desert of Karim Shahi village, near Khavda, Bhuj district near the India-Pakistan border in the western state of Gujarat, India, Thursday, Sept. 21, 2023. Led by new solar power, the world added renewable energy at breakneck speed in 2023, in an effort to turn away from fossil fuels to stave off severe Earth warming and its effects. (AP Photo/Rafiq Maqbool)](https://i.cbc.ca/1.7653270.1759852762!/fileImage/httpImage/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/16x9_620/ye-clean-energy.jpg)
Worldwide solar and wind power generation has outpaced electricity demand this year, and for the first time on record, renewable energies combined generated more power than coal, according to a new analysis.

item.title: Man found guilty of stalking Myleene Klass
item.description: A 61-year-old man has been found guilty of stalking TV and radio star Myleene Klass by posting to her an air pistol, handcuffs, a police uniform and "disturbing" unwanted letters.
item.source:markdown: A 61-year-old man has been found guilty of stalking TV and radio star Myleene Klass by posting to her an air pistol, handcuffs, a police uniform and "disturbing" unwanted letters.

item.title: Minimum wage set to increase to €14.15 an hour in 2026
item.description: The Minister for Finance has announced that as of 1 January 2026, the national minimum wage will increase by €0.65 per hour to €14.15 per hour.
item.source:markdown: The Minister for Finance has announced that as of 1 January 2026, the national minimum wage will increase by €0.65 per hour to €14.15 per hour.

item.title: Peter To Rot's witness of martyrdom and morality
item.description:
The story of Blessed Peter To Rot cannot be told apart from the upheavals of World War II. When Japanese forces occupied Papua New Guinea, foreign missionaries were imprisoned, leaving catechists like To Rot to guide local communities in faith. Blessed Peter To Rot’s defiance of polygamy was his ultimate sacrifice. Archbishop Tatamai gives first hand witnesss from stories told.

Read all
item.source:markdown:
The story of Blessed Peter To Rot cannot be told apart from the upheavals of World War II. When Japanese forces occupied Papua New Guinea, foreign missionaries were imprisoned, leaving catechists like To Rot to guide local communities in faith. Blessed Peter To Rot’s defiance of polygamy was his ultimate sacrifice. Archbishop Tatamai gives first hand witnesss from stories told.
[Read all](https://www.vaticannews.va/en/church/news/2025-10/martyrdom-and-morality-archbishop-tatamai-reflects-on-his-rela.html)

item.title: Sudan's civil war has faded from headlines, but monitors say it's the largest humanitarian crisis in the world
item.description: The UN says more than 12 million Sudanese have been displaced since its civil war began in spring 2023, making it the largest humanitarian crisis in the world. Aid agencies, including Medecins Sans Frontieres, warn the situation could become even more dire if the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces overruns the besieged city of El Fasher in North Darfur.
item.source:markdown:
![Six people huddle together on a cart piled with their few belongings being pulled by a donkey. ](https://i.cbc.ca/1.7652882.1759796652!/fileImage/httpImage/image.JPG_gen/derivatives/16x9_620/sudan-politics-zamzam.JPG)
The UN says more than 12 million Sudanese have been displaced since its civil war began in spring 2023, making it the largest humanitarian crisis in the world. Aid agencies, including Medecins Sans Frontieres, warn the situation could become even more dire if the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces overruns the besieged city of El Fasher in North Darfur.

item.title: Yellowknife's Somba K'e park likely location for residential school monument, gov't confirms
item.description: The Truth and Reconciliation Commission’s Call to Action 82 urges governments across Canada to install a residential school monument in every capital city. Plans are underway to build a memorial in Yellowknife by June 2027.

item.title: Treaty 8 mural transforms vandalized wall in Fort St. John
item.description: After vandals defaced the Treaty 8 office in Fort St. John with racist graffiti, Cree artist Alisa Parenteau picked up her paintbrush and responded with colour, leading a new wave of public art making a splash across the city.
item.source:markdown:

item.title: Why First Nations in B.C. are making statements on ostrich farm cull controversy
item.description: First Nations in B.C. are now among national and international voices that have been pulled into a fight to spare over 300 ostriches in the rural community of Edgewood, east of Kelowna, from a Canada Food Inspection Agency (CFIA) cull.

item.title: Clinic offers addiction treatment to 15 in remote, fly-in community, but dozens more still on waitlist
item.description: An Indigenous-led clinic bringing substance addiction services to Manitoba's Island Lake region has already enrolled 15 patients in treatment for opioid dependency — but officials warn the need for these services is dire and dozens are already sitting on a waitlist.

An Indigenous-led clinic bringing substance addiction services to Manitoba's Island Lake region has already enrolled 15 patients in treatment for opioid dependency — but officials warn the need for these services is dire and dozens are already sitting on a waitlist.

item.title: Parolin on October 7, Gaza: Human beings are not collateral damage
item.description:
The Holy See Secretary of State speaks to Vatican Media on the second anniversary of Hamas's “inhuman” attack on Israel, which unleashed the destruction of the Gaza Strip. He says that what is happening in Gaza is “inhuman”, and that he's struck by the turnout at peace marches. He adds that antisemitism is a cancer that must be eradicated.

item.title: Gaza: Major UN aid operation ‘ready to go’ if agreement is reached on US peace plan
item.description: UN aid teams in Gaza are “ready to go” with thousands of tonnes of supplies on standby to alleviate famine, widespread hunger and malnutrition, in the event of agreement being reached over the US peace plan in the coming days.

item.title: Darfur: ICC convicts Janjaweed leader of war crimes and crimes against humanity
item.description: Two decades after the scorched-earth campaign that left hundreds of thousands dead in Sudan’s Darfur, the International Criminal Court (ICC) has delivered its first conviction linked to the conflict, finding Janjaweed commander Ali Muhammad Ali Abd-Al-Rahman “Ali Kushayb”, guilty of war crimes and crimes against humanity.
item.source:markdown: Two decades after the scorched-earth campaign that left hundreds of thousands dead in Sudan’s Darfur, the International Criminal Court (ICC) has delivered its first conviction linked to the conflict, finding Janjaweed commander Ali Muhammad Ali Abd-Al-Rahman “Ali Kushayb”, guilty of war crimes and crimes against humanity.

item.title: WHO: Despite smoking decline, tobacco still hooks one in five adults worldwide
item.description: Although there are fewer smokers now than 15 years ago, one in five adults worldwide is still hooked on tobacco.
item.source:markdown: Although there are fewer smokers now than 15 years ago, one in five adults worldwide is still hooked on tobacco.

item.title: Women’s leadership role in peace and security issues ‘going in reverse’, UN chief warns
item.description: More women must have a role in shaping peace agreements, security reforms and post-conflict recovery plans, UN Secretary-General António Guterres told the Security Council on Monday.
item.source:markdown: More women must have a role in shaping peace agreements, security reforms and post-conflict recovery plans, UN Secretary-General António Guterres told the Security Council on Monday.

item.title: We are not powerless in face of Gaza, West Bank, Ukraine atrocities, insists UNHCR chief
item.description: The head of the UN refugee agency, UNHCR, on Monday took aim at the “deliberate abandonment” of the laws of war today, while rejecting the idea that the international community is powerless in the face of ongoing violations.

item.title: In landmark labour case, UN World Court weighs in on right to strike
item.description: The International Court of Justice (ICJ) opened hearings on Monday to determine whether the right to strike is protected under international law – the first time the world’s top court has been asked to weigh in on the balance between workers’ rights and employers’ interests.
item.source:markdown: The International Court of Justice (ICJ) opened hearings on Monday to determine whether the right to strike is protected under international law – the first time the world’s top court has been asked to weigh in on the balance between workers’ rights and employers’ interests.

item.description: The UN Secretary-General António Guterres marked two years since the Hamas-led terror attacks on southern Israel by reiterating his long-standing call for the unconditional and immediate release of the hostages still being held there.
item.source:markdown: The UN Secretary-General António Guterres marked two years since the Hamas-led terror attacks on southern Israel by reiterating his long-standing call for the unconditional and immediate release of the hostages still being held there.

item.title: Where despair meets mercy: Church’s mission in Colombian slum
item.description:
In the south of Bogotá, in what was once a middle-class Colombian neighborhood, lies the “Barrio San Bernardo.” Today, this area bears the marks of marginalization and despair, but within it, seeds of hope are being planted by a young parish priest, Fr. Juan Felipe Quevedo.

Read all

item.title: Bishops dedicate Kenya to Mary, Mother of God, during National Prayer Day
item.description:

item.title: Budget 2026: €10 rise in pension, welfare rates expected
item.description: A €10 increase in the State pension and Social Protection rates is expected in today's Budget. The Budget will also see mortgage interest relief, which has benefitted more than 60,000 householders, extended for another year before being gradually phased out in 2027.

item.title: Hamas and Israeli negotiators in Egypt for Gaza talks

item.title: Hamas and Israel open talks in Egypt on Trump peace plan
item.description: Delegations from Hamas and Israel have begun indirect talks in Egypt's Sharm El-Sheikh on ending the nearly two-year war in Gaza, under a plan put forward by US President Donald Trump.

item.title: Pope calls on world leaders to commit to Gaza peace deal

Speaking at the close of Mass in St Peter’s Square, Pope Leo condemns both the “immense suffering” of Gazans and the rise of “antisemitic hatred” worldwide, and expresses his hope that an Israel-Hamas peace deal will be finalised “as soon as possible”.

item.title: Pope Leo XIV encourages rekindling awareness of our missionary vocation
item.description:
At the Mass for the Jubilee of the Missions and of Migrants, Pope Leo encourages us to rekindle awareness of our missionary vocation that springs from a desire to “bring the joy and consolation of the Gospel to everyone,” remembering those in difficulty, and in particular “our migrant brothers and sisters” forced to leave their homelands.

Read all
item.source:markdown:
At the Mass for the Jubilee of the Missions and of Migrants, Pope Leo encourages us to rekindle awareness of our missionary vocation that springs from a desire to “bring the joy and consolation of the Gospel to everyone,” remembering those in difficulty, and in particular “our migrant brothers and sisters” forced to leave their homelands.
[Read all](https://www.vaticannews.va/en/pope/news/2025-10/pope-encourages-rekindling-awareness-of-our-missionary-vocation.html)

item.title: Cruising for clues: researchers say they've found evidence of 1st invasive barnacle in Nunavut
item.description: The Arctic’s cold waters have – for the most part – prevented invasive species from migrating north. But with the Arctic warming up nearly four times faster than anywhere else on Earth, shipping routes are opening up and the region’s waters are losing their thermal barrier against invasive species.
item.source:markdown:
![cruise ship in the ocean, with rockbed nearby. ](https://i.cbc.ca/1.7651062.1759527375!/fileImage/httpImage/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/16x9_620/cruise-ship-near-pond-inlet-nunavut.jpg)
The Arctic’s cold waters have – for the most part – prevented invasive species from migrating north. But with the Arctic warming up nearly four times faster than anywhere else on Earth, shipping routes are opening up and the region’s waters are losing their thermal barrier against invasive species.

item.title: Why U.S. politicians keep #$%& swearing

item.title: In February 2026 relics of St. Francis of Assisi to be on public display
item.description:
The announcement of the public display for veneration comes from the Sacro Convento in Assisi on the day the Church and the world celebrate the feast of the Saint Francis of Assisi. Thanks to the approval of Pope Leo XIV, the body of the Saint, on the occasion of the 800th anniversary of his death, will be moved from his tomb, located in the crypt of the Franciscan basilica, and placed at the foot of the papal altar in the lower church.

Read all

item.title: Yukon First Nation uses holograms to preserve the knowledge of elders
item.description: There are fewer than 12 fluent speakers of Northern Tutchone left in the remote community of Mayo, Yukon – and many of them are elderly.  The First Nation of Na-Cho Nyӓk Dun has turned to technology to help preserve the language.
item.source:markdown:
![A child stands with his back to the camera facing a machine about the size of a large vending machine with a glass front and a person (actually a hologram of a person) seated inside. ](https://i.cbc.ca/1.7650028.1759453598!/fileImage/httpImage/image.JPG_gen/derivatives/16x9_620/hologram-generator.JPG)
There are fewer than 12 fluent speakers of Northern Tutchone left in the remote community of Mayo, Yukon – and many of them are elderly. The First Nation of Na-Cho Nyӓk Dun has turned to technology to help preserve the language.

item.title: More than 350 arrested at pro-Palestine protest in London
item.description: At least 355 people have been arrested over pro-Palestine protests in London which are taking place in defiance of calls by politicians and police bosses to reconsider after the Manchester synagogue terror attack.
item.source:markdown: At least 355 people have been arrested over pro-Palestine protests in London which are taking place in defiance of calls by politicians and police bosses to reconsider after the Manchester synagogue terror attack.

item.title: Latin Patriarch of Jerusalem urges hope and prayer as ceasefire talks advance
item.description:
Cardinal Pierbattista Pizzaballa welcomes signs of a possible ceasefire, calling them “a long-awaited first step,” while urging hope, prayer, and realism. He highlights ongoing suffering and invites the faithful to join a day of prayer for peace on 11 October.

Read all

item.description: Some 137 activists detained by Israel for taking part in a flotilla seeking to deliver aid to Gaza are being flown to Istanbul, Turkey's foreign ministry has said.

item.title: India’s Durga Puja, where worship meets social change
item.description: India’s eastern state of Bengal transformed this week into the world’s largest public art festival - an immersive blend of worship, artistic expression, and social messaging, thanks to an annual Hindu festival known as Durga Puja.

item.title: JRS International Director: Humanitarian aid is a necessity not an option
item.description:
Speaking on the Jubilee of Migrants, Brother Michael Schöpf reminds us that we are responsible for migrants and refugees. Those who are forced to flee their homes should be welcomed and assissted, and he reminds us that doing so should neither be an option nor a burden.

item.title: Gazans hope Trump will force end to two-year-old war
item.description: Exhausted Palestinians in Gaza clung to hopes that US President Donald Trump would keep up pressure on Israel to end a two-year-old war that has killed tens of thousands of people and displaced the entire population of more than two million.

item.title: Russian strikes on Ukraine trains kill one, injure 30
item.description: Two Russian drones struck trains at a station in Ukraine's northern Sumy region, killing one person and injuring about 30 others, officials have said, with Ukraine's foreign minister accusing Moscow of deliberately hitting passenger trains.
item.source:markdown: Two Russian drones struck trains at a station in Ukraine's northern Sumy region, killing one person and injuring about 30 others, officials have said, with Ukraine's foreign minister accusing Moscow of deliberately hitting passenger trains.

item.title: Russian drone strike hits passenger train in Ukraine, killing 1 person and injuring 30
item.description: Two Russian drones struck trains at a station in Ukraine's northern Sumy region, killing one person and injuring about 30 others, officials said on Saturday, with Ukraine's foreign affairs minister accusing Moscow of deliberately hitting passenger trains.
item.source:markdown:
![Smoke rises over a passenger train.](https://i.cbc.ca/1.7651359.1759589835!/fileImage/httpImage/image.JPG_gen/derivatives/16x9_620/ukraine-crisis-attack-sumy-region.JPG)
Two Russian drones struck trains at a station in Ukraine's northern Sumy region, killing one person and injuring about 30 others, officials said on Saturday, with Ukraine's foreign affairs minister accusing Moscow of deliberately hitting passenger trains.

item.title: No one-off measures expected as cost of living looms

item.title: The US budget row that's not about the budget

item.title: In 4 months, Canadian Jeremy Hansen will blast off to the moon — where he'll also be a human guinea pig
item.description: If all goes to plan, next February could see the return of humans to the moon. Four people — NASA astronauts Victor Glover, Reid Wiseman, Christina Koch and Canadian Space Agency astronaut Jeremy Hansen — will see it as no one has before. And they will also be collecting valuable health data on themselves.
item.source:markdown:
![A man in a blue astronaut jumpsuit stands with his arms crossed in front of the blue NASA logo.](https://i.cbc.ca/1.7649483.1759426815!/fileImage/httpImage/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/16x9_620/jeremy-hansen-jsc.jpg)
If all goes to plan, next February could see the return of humans to the moon. Four people — NASA astronauts Victor Glover, Reid Wiseman, Christina Koch and Canadian Space Agency astronaut Jeremy Hansen — will see it as no one has before. And they will also be collecting valuable health data on themselves.

item.title: There could be 'mutual interest' in Canada building its submarines, says German armament secretary
item.description: The notion of Canada becoming a submarine-building nation is not that far-fetched, Germany’s armaments state secretary says. Jens Plötner said ThyssenKrupp Marine Systems — one of two bidders in the submarine program — has done it in other countries and all Canada has to do is ask.
item.source:markdown:
![Four people wear suits and hardhats. One of the holds a model submarine.](https://i.cbc.ca/1.7650905.1759520915!/cpImage/httpImage/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/16x9_620/carney-germany-20250826.jpg)
The notion of Canada becoming a submarine-building nation is not that far-fetched, Germany’s armaments state secretary says. Jens Plötner said ThyssenKrupp Marine Systems — one of two bidders in the submarine program — has done it in other countries and all Canada has to do is ask.

item.title: 13,000 without power after Storm Amy hits Ireland
item.description: Around 13,000 homes and businesses remain without power and a number of flights have been cancelled at Dublin Airport as the impact of Storm Amy continues to be felt around the country.

item.title: Flights resume at Munich airport after drone sightings
item.description: Flights have resumed "progressively" at Munich airport after drone sightings caused a second shutdown in as many days, affecting over 6,500 passengers, the operator said.
item.source:markdown: Flights have resumed "progressively" at Munich airport after drone sightings caused a second shutdown in as many days, affecting over 6,500 passengers, the operator said.
